Dear Miss Bagger,

Thank you very much for your help.

My story is now written down twice. I had intended writing it out but I had a bad fall on the staircase and hurt my right arm and my back. However, I am still able to write and I think this is a good thing.

I am not sure how to begin or end the story. I have written a few pages already when I wrote my memoirs for the National Archives. I did make a few mistakes in the handwriting.

As it stands, I don't think it would make the book interesting. As it needs editing, I have a few copies made for you to edit. You might have a few copies made for me to read.

Yours sincerely,

John Mitchell

Miss Bagger,

Santa, Archivist Officer.

Sanktakotom
Dear Miss Taylor:

Thank you very much for yourself my story manuscript. Am sending you my draft story as written some time ago. I had written a short time ago when I had a bad fall on the staircase which injured my right arm and my back.

I am grateful for your coming on time. I think this is the first time you have visited me in my house. I have been very busy with my work and have not had much opportunity to see you.

As you know, I have been working on my novel "The Greek Mystery." I have finished it and now I am ready to send it to you for editing. You may have a few copies made for me to give to friends.

Yours sincerely,

John Miller

[Signature]

A brief sketch of its history and of the man after whom it was named—W.E. Traill.

Mr. Traill, a retired H.P., Co. officer, decided on retiring to go into cattle raising and knowing of a good location south of the Wetaskiwin Lake (Kintail district), from an old native, investigated, and finding it satisfactory, located on the N.E. 1/4-16-44-22 W and on the bank of the Yellow Creek. He also homesteaded the N.E. section 12 in the same township. Here he erected buildings and put up hay and purchased a herd of good cattle. This in 1887.

In coming to the ranch from Prince Albert he followed the traveled trail to near Kinistino, there south along the west side of Wetaskiwin Lake following an old Indian trail, fording the Carrot River, building a brush bridge over the boggy Willow Creek and fording the Yellow Creek on the east side of which his building stood.

A word about Mr. Traill's background. He was born at Kintail, Ontario to the son of Captain Thomas Traill and Catherine Part Stirketland, his wife. Educated at Peterborough he with a couple of school chums, Ford and Peg, Betty, with the love of adventure strong in their veins decided to go west and join the H.B. Co. Mr. Traill and Ford Beatty getting first reaching Port Garry in 1862.

As apprentice clerk (later his father-in-law), so began his career as a fur trader.

While there he was in charge of various outposts. From one of these he often traveled the old hunting trail (Pt. Ellice, Mt. Lake, Lac Lenore, Basin Lake, and through to Redrobe), passing south of the present Maskawna, this was a rich fur country. The finer furs were very plentiful, fisher, martin, beaver and mink.

It was Saltpeau and Cree country.

From there he was transferred to Cartton serving under Chief Factor Lawrence Clarke. While there he was almost killed by a drunken Indian, to whom he refused liquor and who struck him on the head with an axe injuring him severely.

It was many months before he recovered fully.

From there he was transferred to Cartton serving under Chief Factor William McKay (later his father-in-law). So began his career as a fur trader.

A brief sketch of its history and of the man after whom it was named - W.E. Traill.

Mr. Traill, a retired H.B. Co. officer, decided on retiring to go into cattle raising and knowing of a good location South of the Waterhen Lake (Kinistino district), from an old native, investigated, and finding it satisfactory, located on the N.E. 1/4 16-44-22 W 2nd on the bank of the Yellow Creek. He also homesteaded the N.E. section 12 in the same township. Here he erected buildings and put up hay and purchased a head of good cattle. This in 1887.

In coming to the ranch from Prince Albert he followed the travelled trail to near Kinistino, there south along the west side of Waterhen Lake following an old Indian trail, fording the Carrot River, building a brush bridge over the boggy Willow Creek and fording the Yellow Creek on the east side of which his building stood.

A word about Mr. Traill's background. He was born at Lakefield, Ontario, the son of Captain Thomas Traill and Catherine Parr Strickland, his wife. Educated at Peterborough he with a couple of school chums, Ford and Reg. Beatty, with the love of adventure strong in their veins decided to go west and join the H.B. Co. Mr. Traill and Ford Beatty going first reaching Fort Garry in 1862.

As apprentice clerk Mr. Traill was posted to Fort Ellice serving under William McKay (later his father-in-law). So began his career as a fur trader. While there he was in charge of various outposts. From one of these he often travelled the old hunting trail (Ft. Ellice, Nut Lake, Lac Lenore, Basin Lake, and through to Batoche), passing south of the present Meskanaw. This was a rich fur country. The finer furs were very plentiful, Fisher, Martin, Beaver and Mink. It was Salteaux and Cree country.

From there he was transferred to Carlton serving under Chief Factor Lawrence Clarke. While there he was almost killed by a drunken Indian, to whom he refused liquor and who struck him on the head with an axe injuring him severely. It was many months before he recovered fully.

From there he was transferred to Prince Albert to operate an experimental farm in an effort to see if wheat could be ripened there. While barley could be successfully grown at a number of posts wheat had been a very indifferent crop as frost always got it before it was ripe. The farm was located on the ridge east of Prince Albert.

While at Carlton he played a heroic part during the smallpox epidemic. See Butler report appended.

After leaving Carlton he served as Post manager at several important posts. Amongst them - Fort Pitt, Slave Lake, Vermillion, Fort St. James and others. He retired on pension from Fort St. James B.C. coming to Prince Albert and from there to the present Meskanaw. Meskanaw being a Cree word meaning Trail or Road.
In 1897 his daughter Maria joined him as housekeeper. She was also called settlers and pioneers of the district.

At the Trelill house, some liked the country and decided to homestead there, etc., Albert Owen, W.M. Trelill and John McCloy, others to homestead that year were Mr. Bowser, Thomas McCloy, F.J., McCloy, T.E., McCloy, Walter Trelill, P.J., Hicks, P., Crocker, W., Prewson, T., Wilson and I., Layton, All located within a two mile radius of Keshena. Those who came first opening the way for others.

The Trelill family moved to the ranch in 1900 and they certainly opened their hearts and home to all these newcomers. Some of whom came direct from England others and were very green — very much so. For instance — they put green logs to build their stoves and building them heavy to load decided to take the waste off the wagon and load them on the body. This very old, but when they tried to put the wheels back on — oh well — that's the way to learn.

People lived very simply in those days food being the big problem. In the winter one could kill a steer or pig, were generous that supplies in bulk. This was at times a hard trip due to weather. At other times though it was looked on as a hobby or place to several traveled together and camping out around a fire cooking and burning.

While some supplies could be purchased at Keshena, people had occasionally to go to Prince Albert to purchase their supplies in bulk. This was at times a hard trip due to weather. At other times though it was looked on as a hobby or place to several traveled together and camping out around a fire cooking and burning.

So this wasn't by any means the hardship that some people plante.

Quite a number of settlers came in the next few years. Amongst them — Hansberg, Selness, O'Gordelle, Partridge, Kerr, Larvence and others soon followed.

Some pressing problems came up, viz. a survey of TP. 44-22 W of 2. The surveying of this township had been carelessly done. Only one mound could be found in the whole township.

A road direct to Keshena through Greentop Hill was needed.

It was deemed advisable to have some organization through which they could officially express their desires.

A post office was also a necessity. In order to co-ordinate their efforts it was decided that the same person may be given to the district. The Bee, Press, and the Post Office arose, when we got one, thereby honouring Mr. Trelill, the first settler. (This in 1904.)

At a meeting held in Mr. Trelill's house it was unanimously decided to organize a Green Groves Local. John McCloy was elected President, and John Caldwell, Sec'y. Press, and the Post Office arose, when we got one, thereby honouring Mr. Trelill, the first settler. (This in 1904.)
In 1897 his daughter Maria joined him as housekeeper. She with Alex Dubois, (who was employed by him at that time), are still alive and can be truly called settlers and pioneers of the district.

In 1901 on return from South Africa, Boer War, several young men came to visit the Traill home. Some liked the country and decided to homestead there, viz., Albert Dower, W.M. Traill and John McCloy. Others to homestead that year were Mr. Dover, Thomas McCloy, T.J. McCloy, T.B. McCloy, Walter Traill, F.J. Riggs, P. Crocker, W. Frashton, T. Wilson and L. Clayton. All located within a two mile radius of the present village of Miskanaw. These may be truly called the Pioneers of Miskanaw. "Those who came first opening the way for others."

The Traill family moved to the ranch in 1900 and they certainly opened their hearts and home to all these newcomers. Some of whom came direct from English cities and were very green — very much so. For instance — they cut green logs to build their shacks and finding them heavy to load decided to take the wheels off the wagon and load them on the body. This they did, but when they tried to put the wheels back on — oh well— that's the way to learn.

People lived very simply in those days food being the big problem. In the winter one could kill a steer or pig, but in summer this wasn't easy to handle. However, ducks, prairie chickens and rabbits were plentiful and if one had a gun and most people had, either a muzzle or breachloader, and could buy ammunition the meat problem was solved. For instance, one day Mrs. Traill was out of meat so she gave an old Indian who happened to be there, a gun and two shells (hand loaded) and asked him to get some ducks. In a short time he returned with 17 ducks.

While some supplies could be purchased at Kinistino, people had occasionally to make the trip to Prince Albert to purchase their supplies in bulk. This was at times a hard trip due to weather. At other times though it was looked on as a holiday or picnic if several travelled together and camping out around a fire smoking and yarning.

While there were no graded roads the prairie trails, following the higher ground as they did, were generally good and wood and water were plentiful. So this wasn't by any means the hardship that some people picture.

Quite a number of settlers came in the next few years. Amongst them — Hanberg, Selness, Caldwell, Farstad, Kerr, Lawrences and others soon followed.

Some pressing problems crept up, viz. a resurvey of Tp. 44-22 W of 2. The surveying of this township had been carelessly done. Only one mound could be found in the whole township.

A road direct to Kinistino through Crescent Hill was needed.

A post office was also a necessity. In order to co-ordinate their efforts it was deemed advisable to have some organization through which they could officially express their desires.

At a meeting held in Mr. Traill's home it was unanimously decided to organize a Grain Growers Local. John McCloy was elected President, and John Caldwell, Sec. Treas. It was decided that the name Miskanaw be given to the district. The G.G. local and the Post Office also, when we got one, thereby honouring Mr. Traill, the first settler. (This in 1904.)
The organization carried on more or less efficiently during a little bulk buying in addition to pressing for the re-survey, post office and road.

The matter of re-survey was taken up in the Dominion Government and with our member, Mr. T.O. Devitt, M.P., After some correspondence a request was decided on, provided that each land owner agreed to accept this re-survey as legal and binding. All signed and the re-survey was made.

At a meeting held joint McLoey and John Freeman were named a committee to interview the Crescent Hill people as to their desire for a P.O. A meeting was called together at Mr. Weatherby's house and at this meeting it was agreed that they ask for a P.O. to be named Crescent HILL.

As to the road - In 1905 the first provincial election was held and Mr. Thomas Sanderson, Liberal, was elected. He promised that if elected he would press for the building of this road which he considered necessary. He did - one of the few members who lived up to pre-elected promises.

In the summer of 1906 a survey of the road was made, two bridges built and a grant of money given to fill in the approaches to these bridges and cut some bush from the road allowance. This money grant was a god send to the settlers even if the pay was only $2.50 a day for a man and team, 10 hour day - and he had to feed himself and team.

The Grain Grocers Local carried on with its ups and downs until the amalgamation of the two farm organizations, Grain Grocers and Farmers Union where it boasted a membership of over eighty members (paid up) and was represented at the amalgamation convention by eight delegates whose expenses were fully paid by the local. This showed a healthy state in the local.

The spiritual life of the people was looked after by the Anglican and Presbyterian denominations. Canon Thomas Clarke, an old timer in missionary work, represented the Anglican and various students the Presbyterian. Canon Clarke, an old time traveller carried his blankets with him ready to sleep on the floor either in the Trall home or in a bachelor shack. Mr. Trall donated a parcel of land for a church and grave yard. A church was erected (Anglican). This was later moved to the Meekanaw Village.

The first Presbyterian ordained minister was the Rev. Mr. Murdoch, a very fine man liked by all. Today a United Church stands in the village and takes care of those of that faith.

In 1907 a terrible tragedy occurred a few mile south of the site of the Meekanaw Village. When a family of Selkirk Indians from James Smith Reserve, Naqagawasoo, a Saltbox, his wife and two children, a girl of 16 and a boy of 12, lost their lives. They and some other Indians came from the same reserve were trapping on McGoy Creek near where the old hunting trail crossed it S.E. of Meekanaw. In 1907 a terrible tragedy occurred a few mile south of the site of the
Meekanaw Village. When a family of Saulteaux Indians from James Butts Reserve,
lost their lives. They and some other Indians came from the same reserve were
trapping on McCloy Creek near where the old hunting trail crossed it S.E. of
Meekanaw. On Sunday morning they had a dispute over something and Meekanaw
decided to move to a lake a few miles south of Meekanaw. They had to travel through
A dense bush of poplar killed by fire several years before. It was mostly in windfalls and under a tree that had been standing for several days started up again and burned by a very strong wind caught them and they had no chance of escape. The two children perished and the parents terribly burned. One of the horses although terribly burned was able to travel and the woman, suffering terribly, managed to mount him and ride back to where the other Indians were camped, for help. These brought them out as far as the Dead River and sent a young man to Kinistino for a doctor. The local doctor refused to go. The young chap then went to the station to hire Melfort for a doctor. He had no money and the Station Agent refused to take the wire.

In the meantime a merchant in Kinistino, Mr. Devlinie, wired the Indian Agent at Duck Lake of the tragedy. The wire got there just when it arrived and wired back at once that the agent was on his way to Ft. La Borne and to leave him contacted there. In the meantime have what was necessary done. (No telephones or cars in those days.) Mr. Devlinie did everything.

Everything possible was done for them but both died. They suffered terribly.

The matter of the Station Agent was brought up in parliament by a private member but nothing was done about it.

The whole tragedy might truthfully be traced to a trader who visited the camp on the previous evening.

Today Maskanaw is a thriving district containing some of the best land in Saskatchewan. This is reflected in the many fine homes and the number of elevators to be seen by the many who travel the old 44 Trail. Now a highway.

An extract from the report of Lieut. Butler (later Major General) to Lieut. Governor Archibald of Meniboeuf re the smallpox outbreak at Fort Carillon in July, 1780.

The circumstances attending the progress of the epidemic at Carillon house are worthy of notice both on account of the extreme violence which characterized the disease at that post, and also no official record of this visitation of small-pox would be complete without detailed to bring to the notice of your Excellency the undaunted heroism displayed by a young officer of the Hudson's Bay Company who was in temporary charge of the post.

Throughout the entire period of the epidemic the officer alluded to, Mr. William E. Trall, labored with untiring perseverance in ministering to the necessities of the sick, at whose bedside he was to be found both night and day, under treated by the fear of infection, and undismayed by the unusually loathsome nature of the disease.

At the outbreak of the disease, early in August, the population of Carillon numbered about 70 souls. Of these 32 persons caught the disease and 25 died.

Mr. Trall was the first settler in Maskanaw, which was named after him (Maskanaw being a Cree word meaning trail or road). He was postmaster until his death.

A brief sketch of its history - of the man after whom it was named - Mr. McCloy.

Mr. McCloy, a retired H.B.C. officer, decided on returning to settle cattle raising & farming in a good location south of the Waterton lake (Kumala district) from an old valley investigated & found suitable for settlement on the NE'4 SW'16. 40 acres was on the bank of the Yellow Creek. He also homesteaded the NE'8 SW'12 in the same township. He erected building of fruit of bay purchased a herd of good cattle which in 1897.

Moving to the ranch from Prince Albert to follow the Trans-Canada Trail he met Indians, plainsmen along the west side of Waterton following an old Indian trail, founding the Carpole River, building bridge over the brook William Creek & founding Creek on the east side of which his building stood.

A word about Mr. McCloy's background. He was born at Port Hope, Ontario. His son Capt. Thomas McCloy of Catharine Park, Strathcona, educated at Princeton College with a couple of college chums, will join the H.B.C. Co. this fall - P.M.A. Butte going first marching four years in 1862.

As apprentice clerk when he was posted to Fort Belknap, serving under William Hickey (later his brother-in-law) so began his career as fur trader. While there he was in charge of various outfits. In 1879 he left Fort Belknap for Fort Walsh, Saskatchewan, passing south of the prairie house - where very pleasant Fisher Norton Brown's ranch.

Mr. McCloy came country.
A brief sketch of its history of the man after whom it was named—Mr. McCloy.

Mr. McCloy, a retired H.B.C. officer, decided on returning to raise cattle raising a homestead on location south of the water hole (Kumaloo district) from an old native investigation, finding satisfactory located on the NE¼ Sec. 16, 44.22. was on the bank of Yellow Creek. He also homesteaded the NE¼ Sec. 12 in the same township. He erected building of half a way, purchased a herd of good cattle. When in 1897.

He came to the ranch from Prince Albert to follow the Trans-Canada Trail to meet civilization, then south along the west side of Saskatchewan following an old Indian trail, founding the Carrot River, building through bridge over the brook Willow Creek, founding the Willow Creek on the east side of which his building stood.

A word about his family's background. He was born at Elkford, Ontario. His son John McCloy married Miss Catherine Parr Strickland in 1862 and they raised their family in the community.

The family moved to Prince Albert in 1862.

As an apprentice clerk he was posted to Fort Belcher, serving under William McCloy (Sr.) in Saskatchewan. So began his career as foreman, while there he was in charge of numerous outfits.

A hunting trip (Mr. McCloy, Mr. John McCloy, Mr. James McCloy) passing south of the homestead back—amazingly, they were a mix of cowboys, farmers, and ranchers.

We won Salt Lake City and Cass County.
From there he was transferred to Carlton burning under Chief Factor Donald Clark. While there he was almost killed by a drunken Indians but when he refused to give them a ride on his back with an eye injury him severely. He was many months before he recovered fully.

From there he was transferred to Prince Albert to operate an experimental farm in an effort to see if wheat could be raised there. Used badly until his unexpectedly grown at a number of points where he had been very indifferent and found ordinary grain before his wife. The farm was located on the ridge near Prince Albert.

While at Carlton he played a minor part during the Smallpox epidemic. Sir Butler report officially appointed Carlton for service as Postmaster at Smallpox Station. Mr. Wilson on permission from Port St. James, P.E.I., coming to Prince Albert from Port St. John, N.B., coming to Prince Albert being a cure worth making trial on Roma.

Ronnie McCloy was a man from New Orleans. He was a blacksmith and a good friend to all.

One day Ronnie went to town to buy some nails. As he walked down the street, he heard someone say:

"Hey, Ronnie! You're going to New Orleans?"

Ronnie turned around and saw his friend, Jack.

"Jack, what's going on?" Ronnie asked.

"I'm going to New Orleans," Jack replied.

"Why are you going there?" Ronnie asked.

"To see my family," Jack said.

Ronnie looked at Jack and then looked back at the street. He realized that Jack was right. Ronnie had been going to New Orleans every year for years.

Ronnie decided to visit New Orleans more often in the future. He knew that he would always be welcome there.

An extract from the report of Judge Bucoler (Later Major General) Co. Iota.

Governor Archibald of Hamilton to the smallpox outbreak at Fort Carleton in July, 1870.

The circumstances attending the progress of the epidemic at Carleton house are worthy of notice both on account of the extreme vulnerece which characterized the disease at that post, and also no official record of this visitation of smallpox would be complete without added to bring to the notice of your Excellency the undiminished display of a young officer of the Hudson's Bay Company who was in temporary charge of the Post.

At the outbreak of the disease, early in August, the population of Carleton numbered about 70 souls. Of these 32 persons caught the disease and 25 died. Throughout the entire period of the epidemic the officer alluded to, Mr. William B. Trall, labored with untiring perseverance in ministering to the necessaries of the sick, at whose bedside he was to be found both night and day, undeterred by the fear of infection, and immediately by the unusually loathsome nature of the disease.

Mr. Trall was the first settler in Moskau, which was named after him (Moskauw being a groo word meaning trail or road). He was postmaster until his death.

The circumstances attending the progress of the epidemic at Carlton house are worthy of notice both on account of the extreme virulence which characterized the disease at that post and also no official record of this visitation of smallpox would be complete which failed to bring to this notice of Your Excellency the undaunted heroism displayed by a young officer of the Hudson's Bay Company who was in temporary charge of the Post.
